{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3335472,"name":"Riley A","username":"RileyA","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rileya/{size}/199540_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T23:38:41.248Z","cooked":"

My team is considering getting Swerve by the end of this season (we already finished our competitions). I was wondering what parts could be CNCed, as well as what we need to buy if we CNC those. We have a Haas that can cut in 3 axes.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-18T15:43:22.243Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":42,"reads":726,"readers_count":725,"score":370.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":"Riley A","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60359,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3335519,"name":"Ty Tremblay","username":"Ty_Tremblay","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ty_tremblay/{size}/219248_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-18T00:27:16.069Z","cooked":"

Don’t do it.

If you want swerve by the end of the season, buy swerve.

REV, SDS, WCP and others sell fully functional swerve systems.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-18T00:27:16.069Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":701,"readers_count":700,"score":370.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":"Ty Tremblay","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":28}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6115,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2713 | RSN"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/2","custom_user_title":"2713 | RSN","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":15},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":12},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":28,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335532,"name":"jedgar6","username":"jedgar6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jedgar6/{size}/200602_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-18T00:41:15.387Z","cooked":"
Ty_Tremblay:

Don’t do it.

You may read this and think it’s blunt but it’s the honest truth. You don’t gain very much from making your own custom swerve and it will continue to cost a lot of money.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-18T00:41:15.387Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":664,"readers_count":663,"score":227.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":"jedgar6","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33848,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9410"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/3","custom_user_title":"9410","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335625,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-18T02:03:10.641Z","cooked":"
jedgar6:

don’t gain very much

OP will gain invaluable experience in design and fabrication not to mention the experience of great frustration of not having a functioning drive train. My team failed miserably and we started with an allegedly good design that was mostly fabricated professionally by one of our sponsors. We then bought SDS so we had a robot that moved for more than a few minutes.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-18T02:03:10.641Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":612,"readers_count":611,"score":252.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":9}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":9,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335644,"name":"Pat Mattin","username":"pmattin5459","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pmattin5459/{size}/182786_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-18T02:27:21.737Z","cooked":"

Define “end of the season.” Are you attempting to enter this drivetrain in an event within the next few weeks? I would never advise building a drivetrain that is new to you within build season, and definitely not after competition season has started. Any advantage you may get from your fancier drivetrain is negated by lost driver practice and the likelihood of becoming very similar to a brick (heavy and immobile) once you hit the field due to unforeseen issues.

If you’re building swerve in preparation for next season, I would advise building one of the COTS options first. You’ll be able to test code and start driving with a proven solution. Then think about what modifications you could make to the COTS design to improve it.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-18T02:32:50.999Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":573,"readers_count":572,"score":114.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":"Pat Mattin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27664,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Cheesecake Enthusiast"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/5","custom_user_title":"Cheesecake Enthusiast","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335833,"name":"Carlos Reckner","username":"GlassMaker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/glassmaker/{size}/9548_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-18T13:18:08.912Z","cooked":"

As the others have said, if this is for this season do not do it. The time required to design a swerve, create all of the CNC code, and all of the fixturing required is high. This is definitely an off-season project.

We do design and machine our own swerves for our bots. The benefit for us is that it teaches our students machining skills and we can manipulate the design as needed for the game. The downside is that it costs us in time to manufacture our drives each season.

If you really want to make you own drives I would recommend that you start with a COTs option to allow you to get your software in order first. That way you know you have a good working software platform to start with. Without that you will be wondering is it the software or is it the drive that you made. Once you have software sorted, get step files from a COTs option or from a team that makes their own and then see if you can replicate the parts by creating the CNC code and machining the parts. Compare the parts you make to what they should be. Measure everything to see that you are making parts correctly. Fit the made parts into the COTs option to see how well they fit up.

Just understand that it is very time intensive, especially when you are just starting, and will consume a fair amount of time from your team to make drives and you will need to consider how much time it will take up for your team. Also remember that while your CNC is making drives it is not available to make other components for your bot.

That said it does teach how to set up CNC systems and fixturing to make more complex parts so it can have benefits. Your team will need to carefully weigh if the added time is worth it for you.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-18T13:18:08.912Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":489,"readers_count":488,"score":97.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":"Carlos Reckner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30057,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 103 | Learn all you can. Teach all you can."},"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/6","custom_user_title":"Team 103 | Learn all you can. Teach all you can.","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3336752,"name":"Ardiano Works","username":"MSU2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msu2000/{size}/190139_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-19T03:34:32.072Z","cooked":"

Should you? No. Buy off shelf, run the heck out of it, make some changes to your like, then CNC those parts.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-19T03:34:47.288Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":360,"readers_count":359,"score":77.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":"Ardiano Works","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57747,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3336773,"name":"Cory","username":"Cory","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cory/{size}/312_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-19T04:42:19.759Z","cooked":"

But also don’t even do that.

Switching to OTS swerve from custom 6WD was the biggest reduction in manufacturing burden we’ve ever done. It saved us literally a week of fabrication.

You could save money making your own, but it ain’t worth it, unless you literally can’t afford to buy it.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-19T04:42:19.759Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":376,"readers_count":375,"score":290.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":"Cory","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57747,"username":"MSU2000","name":"Ardiano Works","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msu2000/{size}/190139_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":17}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":1037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":14},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":17,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3336803,"name":null,"username":"holonomic","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/c2a13f/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-19T05:41:33.589Z","cooked":"

I will offer a slightly different perspective as someone whose team (4904) did do custom swerve.

Over last offseason, we worked with a student on 840 who was particularly interested in making a custom module to design a compact swerve drive roughly similar to swerveXS. Between meeting less frequently and working out kinks in fabrication, we didn’t have a functional testbed drivetrain until week one of build season.

Even starting from commercially available parts as we did, machining plates, turntable gears, and wheel forks during is very time consuming, and verges on impractical during build season as is required by the rules. We were able to cut a good bit of time by 3D printing our wheel forks, but swerve still wasn’t fully machined and assembled til week 5 of build. We’re fairly lucky in the fact that we have a 4 axis mill and CNC router at our disposal, but even then fixturing and setup time will really eat in to your productivity when you move beyond simple tubing and plate like you would need to for a swerve module.

It certainly can be done, and you will learn a lot along the way. But it’s important to understand just how much time and labor you sacrifice when you choose to go custom over an off the shelf option.

(For anyone curious to see our robot in action, I’ve linked a VOD of one of our SFR quals matches)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fgT4AL4zBKI&list=PLZT9pIgNOV6ZNJvXZPepxhOOI7zQ_eG4S&index=65

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-19T05:41:33.589Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":327,"readers_count":326,"score":150.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fgT4AL4zBKI&list=PLZT9pIgNOV6ZNJvXZPepxhOOI7zQ_eG4S&index=65","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":32},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/splinexs-broach-group-buy-interest/463206/32","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"SplineXS Broach Group Buy Interest","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3336895,"name":"Gdeaver","username":"Gdeaver","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/2acd7d/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-19T12:55:32.273Z","cooked":"

I have a different perspective. 1640 has been making our swerves since 2010. It has become ingrained in our culture. I push each year to keep on making them in house. I do this for the students. It is a project that mirrors a real world engineering design build project. Everything from preparing a BOM, purchasing plan, manufacturing schedule, etc, teaches our whole team some really important life skills. We save allot of money and there is the pride I see in the students. I find it very rewarding when the students hold up a swerve module and say " we made this". The planning, design and manufacturing process of our module spills over into the process of other robot sub systems. I use it to instill the engineering mind set into our students. Each year our our team hopefully we graduate a group of students that will go into the world with the " I’ll make that for you and take your money. Allot of your money" instead of the “do it for me” mindset. 1640 will probably always make our swerves. I could go on a rant here but I’ll stop.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-19T12:55:32.273Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":236,"readers_count":235,"score":97.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":"Gdeaver","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3300,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3337036,"name":"Cory","username":"Cory","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cory/{size}/312_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-19T15:15:13.053Z","cooked":"

It sounds like your students are learning a lot which is great.

On the flip side, if I spent weeks at work designing something and having it fabricated (whether internally or outsourced), that I could have bought an equivalent OTS version of, that would be a pretty bad trade.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-19T15:15:13.053Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":166,"readers_count":165,"score":123.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459028,"topic_slug":"how-to-cnc-swerve","display_username":"Cory","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":3300,"username":"Gdeaver","name":"Gdeaver","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/2acd7d/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":1037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-cnc-swerve/459028/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3337072,"name":"kgzak","username":"kgzak","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kgzak/{size}/157079_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-19T15:32:08.839Z","cooked":"

We build our own swerve every year. I think it’s cool and for us it is sort of the cheaper option. Budget is usually our biggest constraint for cots things so it works for us. The only reason it is cheaper for us though is because we can get most of the materials donated. But when people ask me why we build our own swerve, my answer is usually “because we are dumb.” Arguably we would be better off without a custom swerve, but we like to do it.

If your plan is to cut the plates for a swerve that you can just buy, don’t. It’s not worth it. If there is some other constraint that you are working around there might be a better way than to build a custom swerve.
